title: Flyingjack123
author: Flyingjack123
content: For long I read bitcoin isn't environment friendly and the cost of bitcoin mining is exorbitant. This is the main reason why many organisations and governments are criticizing bitcoin.However i feel defferent.I feel bitcoin can become a great tool of creating a much cleaner and greener environment. We should come together and work to create a better future world.Most of the cities around the globe produce tons of waste and that waste end up in landfills, garbage hills, drains and so on.Civic bodies don't really have capability, resources or even will to address these problems.I feel if we allow bitcoiners to set biodegradation plants  for waste treatment. Such plants which decompose these waste and generate bio-gases like methane and other which can inturn generate electricity sufficient for running their bitcoin grids.This will be a win win situation for all.There will be cheap electricity for bitcoin mining , there will be biodegradation of waste as needed by civic bodies.There will be greener and cleaner environment.Overtime  an international  network or a global bitcoin grid, where citizens can invest for creating waste biodegradation plants and the bitcoin mined will be their reward in proportion to their investments.I think bitcoin is an opportunity to bring together world and achieve the mammoth goals of environmental protection, poverty eradication and bringing prosperity and equality in world.Please express your thoughts on this.

comments.author: jackg
comments.body: The energy companies are against carbon neutrality and fixing the problems they caused.The issue with biofuel I can think of is it still produces waste gasses (but does reduce overall waste and might redirect some but landfill is normally compacted well to do that too - the waste normally isn't allowed to breathe for long).I was looking into using renewables for crypto mining and it looks like they might pay higher than directly connecting them to the grid (for smaller sized operations) as the power companies normally only offer half the price of the electricity in return while it's generated (although that was taken from solar and I was looking into wind). That being said, at $400-2k a miner and $3-6k a wind turbine to power it there's probably a reason there aren't that many people doing it.

comments.author: Mate2237
comments.body: There are some questions or threads we see here mables me. What bitcoin has to do with environment again? Bitcoin is an online or a digital currency which can be used to buy goods and services and if the  service providers accept it. so I don't see any connection between the two. But if you understand bitcoin you would not ask such question. What your Fiat currency can do bitcoin can also do if only the environmental service agencies will accept it then bitcoin can be used.

comments.author: o_e_l_e_o
comments.body: Quote from: Flyingjack123 on October 03, 2022, 02:17:32 PMI am a biological scientistI have long argued that bitcoin mining not only uses a completely inconsequential amount of electricity in the wider scheme of things, but also uses a much higher proportion of renewable electricity than almost any other sector and is actively beneficial in the development of new renewable infrastructure.But, here's my question to you as a biological scientist about your proposal: What is stopping the development and building of these bio-degradation plants right now? If they can reduce waste while producing usable energy or electricity which can be sold at a profit, then why do we not have more of them already? Why would sticking a bitcoin mining operation on the side make any difference?

comments.body: If Bitcoin bankrupts banks and the military industrial complex, it will have done more for the environment than anything in history.

comments.author: PeRo
comments.body: Bitcoin is mostly environment friendly since it is digital rather than physical but the claims that Bitcoin does use a lot of electricity are true. Mining is an expensive process and big miner farms use a big amount of electricity and when you put it all on paper - Bitcoin uses as much as electricity as some countries, at least that what most articles about this matter claim. I think it's more of a negative comment on Bitcoin than an actual worry about the environment since there are much bigger threats (as you have mentioned) to it than just Bitcoin and they haven't been questioned for a long time now because it isn't anything new, but Bitcoin is.

comments.body: Yeah it can and I talk about it extensively on https://bitcoincleanup.com (scroll down to "bitcoin mining can help the environment", I'll add an anchor link for that soon).

comments.body: Bitcoin is a currency and a decentralized currency, so Bitcoin doesn't have anything to do with environmental sanitation or environmental clean up, the way i have seen it. Unless you know exactly the aspect you are emphasising on. And secondly bitcoin can be compared with fiat currency, if fiat currency can be used for environmental clean up in any condition bitcoin can do also. Except that i did not comprehend well of what you meant by environmental clean up.

comments.author: dothebeats
comments.body: Yeah, no. Pretty much another unwanted expenditure on the part of the mining firms that it's best to leave the waste as it is and just focus on their main goal: make bitcoin. The idea you outlined is great, although its implementation would require shaving tons of resources from these mining firms. Perhaps some of them can start a movement, but I doubt that they'll ever do that. Recycling waste and turning it into energy is a good thing, but would the energy generated be worth the hassle anyway? Would it remove their 100% dependency on the grid? I don't think so.

comments.author: 348Judah
comments.body: I think from OP approach he meant that there should be alternative means whereby bitcoin could benefit and widens it application in providing a lasting solution in some particular aspect of the economy such as how it imoact could contribute to the development of an environment by making it less concerned in destroying it, bitcoin could be profitable enough in building a good and stable friendly environment, using bitcoin in securing valuables that could contribute to the growth of an environment is also a good and welcome idea aside the currency and asset usage which is the common use.

comments.author: Beefcake
comments.body: I always thought the anti btc argument based on energy usage was flawed. Why not go after Walmart? They use a ton of energy. Or tv sets. People don't need those, they use lots of power. Why not computers in general? Or Ford motor company, or air conditioning, etc. To single out bitcoin seems strange. Lots of stuff uses lots of power, and yet this one thing is singled out. I think it has more to do with the traditional banking system putting out negative stuff about crypto, although I don't know how I would prove such a thing. But, many media outlets are owned by just a handful of people. Technology in general is creating more electricity demand. Look at the insane policy in California, where they want all cars to be electric? But where will this electricity come from? They already have rolling blackouts in the summer. The electricity prices, already some of the most expensive in the world, will become even worse. But that's just an example. In general tech will require more energy, so I think we need better ways of making that energy. In the usa we still use some pretty old school stuff like coal power. Time to invest in new power, rather than attacking a particular technology.

Like solar and hydroelectric energy for which I've seen myself in some docus and stories that I've watched because I was interested into knowing how they do it.Those farm owners have that idea too since they're also worried about high cost of electricity if they will not find a way to have that alternate source of electricity.
